nexttext: \noindent where $E_{\rm i}=\frac{1}{2}\rho_{\rm p}V_{\rm p} v_{\rm i}^2$ with particle volume $V_{\rm p}$ is the kinetic energy of the particle before the impact and $\Delta E_{\rm diss}$ is the total amount of energy loss during the impact. $\Delta E_{\rm diss}$ includes the energy dissipation associated with inelastic solid body interactions~$\Delta E_{\rm dry}$ and the additional contribution from the wetting liquid $\Delta E_{\rm wet}$. Assuming that the two sources of kinetic energy loss are not coupled with each other, we have
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e_{\rm n}=\sqrt{1-\frac{\Delta E_{\rm diss}}{E_{\rm i}}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>diss</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent where $e_{\rm dry}=\sqrt{1-\Delta E_{\rm dry}/E_{\rm i}}$ is the COR for dry impact. The energy loss from the wetting liquid $\Delta E_{\rm wet}$ has three main contributions: Surface energy due to the distorted liquid surface in both penetrating and rebouncing regimes, kinetic energy of the wetting liquid being mobilized $\Delta E_{\rm acc}$, and the energy dissipation from the viscous drag force $\Delta E_{\rm visc}$. The contribution from the surface energy can be ignored in the range of particle sizes focused here, because it is at least one order of magnitude smaller than $\Delta E_{\rm diss}$~\cite{Gollwitzer2012}. Taking the other two terms into account, Eq.~\ref{eq:enEdis} can be rewritten as
prevtext: \noindent where $E_{\rm i}=\frac{1}{2}\rho_{\rm p}V_{\rm p} v_{\rm i}^2$ with particle volume $V_{\rm p}$ is the kinetic energy of the particle before the impact and $\Delta E_{\rm diss}$ is the total amount of energy loss during the impact. $\Delta E_{\rm diss}$ includes the energy dissipation associated with inelastic solid body interactions~$\Delta E_{\rm dry}$ and the additional contribution from the wetting liquid $\Delta E_{\rm wet}$. Assuming that the two sources of kinetic energy loss are not coupled with each other, we have
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e_{\rm n}=\sqrt{e_{\rm dry}^{2}-\frac{\Delta E_{\rm wet}}{E_{\rm i}}}," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>dry</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>wet</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent As the velocity of the liquid being pushed sidewards $v_{\rm l}$ arises from the penetration of the particle into the liquid film, we consider $v_{\rm l}\propto v_{\rm i}$ (see below for a more quantitative analysis). Consequently, we have $\Delta E_{\rm acc}\propto E_{\rm i}$. As the viscous drag force $\propto v_{\rm i}$, we consider the corresponding energy dissipation term $\Delta E_{\rm visc}\propto v_{\rm i}$. Thus, Eq.\,\ref{eq:enEdis2} can be rewritten as
prevtext: \noindent where $e_{\rm dry}=\sqrt{1-\Delta E_{\rm dry}/E_{\rm i}}$ is the COR for dry impact. The energy loss from the wetting liquid $\Delta E_{\rm wet}$ has three main contributions: Surface energy due to the distorted liquid surface in both penetrating and rebouncing regimes, kinetic energy of the wetting liquid being mobilized $\Delta E_{\rm acc}$, and the energy dissipation from the viscous drag force $\Delta E_{\rm visc}$. The contribution from the surface energy can be ignored in the range of particle sizes focused here, because it is at least one order of magnitude smaller than $\Delta E_{\rm diss}$~\cite{Gollwitzer2012}. Taking the other two terms into account, Eq.~\ref{eq:enEdis} can be rewritten as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e_{\rm n}\approx\sqrt{e_{\rm dry}^{2}-\frac{\Delta E_{\rm acc}}{E_{\rm i}}-%
\frac{\Delta E_{\rm visc}}{E_{\rm i}}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></msub><mo>≈</mo><msqrt><mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>dry</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>acc</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>visc</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent where $\alpha=e_{\rm dry}^2-\Delta E_{\rm acc}/E_{\rm i}$ and $\beta=-v_{\rm i}\Delta E_{\rm visc}/E_{\rm i}$ are $v_{\rm i}$ independent parameters. Since ${\rm St} \propto v_{\rm i}$, the linear decay of $e_{\rm n}$ with ${\rm St}^{-1}$ observed above can be treated as a first order approximation of Eq.\,\ref{eq:envi}. 

Moreover, Eq.\,\ref{eq:envi} can be used to predict the two fit parameters. On one hand, $e_{\rm inf}$, the wet COR at St$\to\infty$, can be estimated with

Consequently, we have $\Delta E_{\rm acc}\propto E_{\rm i}$. As the viscous drag force $\propto v_{\rm i}$, we consider the corresponding energy dissipation term $\Delta E_{\rm visc}\propto v_{\rm i}$. Thus, Eq.\,\ref{eq:enEdis2} can be rewritten as

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E4.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e_{\rm n}=\sqrt{\alpha+\frac{\beta}{v_{\rm i}}}=\sqrt{\alpha}(1+\frac{\beta}{2%
\alpha}\frac{1}{v_{\rm i}}-\frac{\beta}{8\alpha}\frac{1}{v_{\rm i}^{2}}+\ldots)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mi>α</mi><mo>+</mo><mfrac><mi>β</mi><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mrow><msqrt><mi>α</mi></msqrt><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>β</mi><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mi>β</mi><mrow><mn>8</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>α</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">…</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent It shows that the saturated value of the wet COR is always smaller than $e_{\rm dry}$, in agreement with the experimental results shown in Fig.\,\ref{fig:envi}. Moreover, Eq.\,\ref{eq:ec} indicates that the difference between $e_{\rm dry}$ and $e_{\rm inf}$ arises from the energy taken by the inertia of the wetting liquid. 

On the other hand, a former analysis based on the lubrication theory~\cite{Gollwitzer2012} shows that
prevtext:
\noindent where $\alpha=e_{\rm dry}^2-\Delta E_{\rm acc}/E_{\rm i}$ and $\beta=-v_{\rm i}\Delta E_{\rm visc}/E_{\rm i}$ are $v_{\rm i}$ independent parameters. Since ${\rm St} \propto v_{\rm i}$, the linear decay of $e_{\rm n}$ with ${\rm St}^{-1}$ observed above can be treated as a first order approximation of Eq.\,\ref{eq:envi}. 

Moreover, Eq.\,\ref{eq:envi} can be used to predict the two fit parameters. On one hand, $e_{\rm inf}$, the wet COR at St$\to\infty$, can be estimated with
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e_{\rm inf}=\sqrt{\alpha}=\sqrt{e_{\rm dry}^{2}-\frac{\Delta E_{\rm acc}}{E_{%
\rm i}}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>inf</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mi>α</mi></msqrt><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>dry</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup><mo>-</mo><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>acc</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent where $\delta_{\rm r}$ and $\epsilon$ are the rupture distance of the liquid bridge and the roughness of the particle, respectively. In this estimation, it was assumed that the lubrication force applies during the whole impact period. This assumption becomes violated if the liquid film thickness is much larger than the critical separation distance $\delta_{\rm c}$, below which the lubrication theory applies~\cite{Davis02}. Since the lubrication theory predicts a diverging viscous force as the separation distance approaches $0$, we may consider that most of the energy loss due to the viscous force takes place within $\delta_{\rm c}$ and estimate the viscous damping term with
prevtext:
\noindent It shows that the saturated value of the wet COR is always smaller than $e_{\rm dry}$, in agreement with the experimental results shown in Fig.\,\ref{fig:envi}. Moreover, Eq.\,\ref{eq:ec} indicates that the difference between $e_{\rm dry}$ and $e_{\rm inf}$ arises from the energy taken by the inertia of the wetting liquid. 

On the other hand, a former analysis based on the lubrication theory~\cite{Gollwitzer2012} shows that

\epsilon}}+\ln{\frac{\delta_{\rm r}}{\epsilon}})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>visc</mi></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><mi>δ</mi><mi>ϵ</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi></msub><mi>ϵ</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent Inserting it into the definition of $\beta$, we have
prevtext: \noindent where $\delta_{\rm r}$ and $\epsilon$ are the rupture distance of the liquid bridge and the roughness of the particle, respectively. In this estimation, it was assumed that the lubrication force applies during the whole impact period. This assumption becomes violated if the liquid film thickness is much larger than the critical separation distance $\delta_{\rm c}$, below which the lubrication theory applies~\cite{Davis02}. Since the lubrication theory predicts a diverging viscous force as the separation distance approaches $0$, we may consider that most of the energy loss due to the viscous force takes place within $\delta_{\rm c}$ and estimate the viscous damping term with
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E7.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Delta E_{\rm visc}=3\pi\eta D^{2}v_{\rm i}\ln{\frac{\delta_{\rm c}}{\epsilon}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>visc</mi></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mi>ϵ</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent Note the essential role of the Stokes number here. Inserting Eqs.\,\ref{eq:ec} and \ref{eq:beta} into Eq.\,\ref{eq:envi} and taking the first order approximation, we have
prevtext: \noindent Inserting it into the definition of $\beta$, we have
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E8.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\beta=-\frac{36\eta v_{\rm i}}{\rho_{\rm p}Dv_{\rm i}}\ln{\frac{\delta_{\rm c}%
}{\epsilon}}=-\frac{4v_{\rm i}}{\rm St}\ln{\frac{\delta_{\rm c}}{\epsilon}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mi>β</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>36</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>η</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>D</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mi>ϵ</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>4</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mrow><mi>St</mi></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mi>ϵ</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext: \noindent Note the essential role of the Stokes number here. Inserting Eqs.\,\ref{eq:ec} and \ref{eq:beta} into Eq.\,\ref{eq:envi} and taking the first order approximation, we have
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E9.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="e_{\rm n}=e_{\rm inf}(1-\frac{{\rm St_{c}}}{\rm St})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>e</mi><mi>inf</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>St</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mi>St</mi></mfrac></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent Thus, the scaling of $e_{\rm n}$ with the Stokes number observed in the experiments is captured by the model. 

As the next step, we discuss the dependency of the fit parameters on $\tilde{\delta}$. Starting from a former analysis~\cite{Gollwitzer2012}, we characterize the relative energy loss from the inertial effect with
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\rm St_{c}}=\frac{2\ln{\frac{\delta_{\rm c}}{\epsilon}}}{e_{\rm inf}^{2}}." display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>St</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mi>ln</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mfrac><msub><mi>δ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msub><mi>ϵ</mi></mfrac></mrow></mrow><msubsup><mi>e</mi><mi>inf</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mfrac></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
\noindent where $V_{\rm l}$ is the volume of the liquid being expelled, and $\tilde{\rho}=\rho_{\rm l}/\rho_{\rm p}$ is the density ratio between the liquid and the particle. The factor $2$ arises from the existence of inertial effects in both penetrating (liquid being repelled from the gap) and rebouncing (liquid being sucked into the gap) regimes. Here, the horizontal velocity of the liquid $v_{\rm l}$ is estimated with the base radius of the spherical cap over the penetrating time $\delta/v_{\rm i}$, where the particle is assumed to penetrate through the liquid film with the impact velocity $v_{\rm i}$. 

Stepping further, we propose a more detailed model for $v_{\rm l}$, considering the stepwise approaching and receding of the particle. As illustrated in the inset of Fig.\,\ref{fig:Eint}(a), we consider the case of a spherical particle penetrating into a liquid film from a depth of $h$ (solid circle) to $h+dh$ (long dashed circle). Assuming the immersed part to be a spherical cap, we can estimate the volume of liquid being pushed sidewards with $V_{\rm cap}=\pi h^2(D/2-h/3)$ and the radius of the three phase contact line with the base radius $r_{\rm b}=\sqrt{h(D-h)}$. As the dimension of the container is much larger than that of the particle, we consider the film thickness $\delta$ to be constant during the impact. Consequently, we have $dV_{\rm cap}=\pi h(D-h)dh$ and a corresponding horizontal movement of
prevtext:
\noindent Thus, the scaling of $e_{\rm n}$ with the Stokes number observed in the experiments is captured by the model. 

As the next step, we discuss the dependency of the fit parameters on $\tilde{\delta}$. Starting from a former analysis~\cite{Gollwitzer2012}, we characterize the relative energy loss from the inertial effect with
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\frac{\Delta E_{\rm acc}}{E_{\rm i}}=\frac{2\rho_{\rm l}V_{\rm l}v_{\rm l}^{2}%
}{\rho_{\rm p}V_{\rm p}v_{\rm i}^{2}}\approx 2\tilde{\rho}\tilde{\delta}(3-5%
\tilde{\delta}+2\tilde{\delta}^{2})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>E</mi><mi>acc</mi></msub></mrow><msub><mi>E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">l</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>v</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi><mn>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac><mo>≈</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>-</mo><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mover accent="true"><mi>δ</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mn>2</mn></msup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: \noindent Due to momentum transfer, the liquid surrounding the particle is accelerated in the direction normal to the contact surface. However, the presence of the horizontal plane effectively guides the streamline to the horizontal direction. Suppose the change of flow direction is extremely efficient, we can estimate the velocity of the liquid being pushed sidewards with
